channel.title: Community News on Jakarta® EE: The New Home of Cloud Native Java
channel.description: Recent content in Community News on Jakarta® EE: The New Home of Cloud Native Java

item.title: The top 25 greatest Java apps ever written
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Millions of developers program in Java. Although Java continues to evolve at an ever-faster pace, on the occasion of the platform’s 25th anniversary, Java Magazine decided to take a look back at how Java molded our planet. The Eclipse IDE, Eclipse Collections and Eclipse GlassFish are mentioned as a few of the countless Java apps that stand out from the crowd.

item.title: Kickstart a Jakarta EE 8 Application
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE 8 starter is a boilerplate project to help you to bootstrap a new Java EE 8/Jakarta EE 8 application in seconds.

item.title: Eclipse Foundation Delivers on Jakarta EE Promise
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation today announced the general availability of Jakarta Enterprise Edition (EE) 8 Full Platform and Web Profile specifications and associated technology compatibility kits (TCKs).

item.title: Eclipse Jakarta EE Arrives
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Two years after taking over Java EE from Oracle, the Eclipse Foundation has shipped its implementation of Java EE 8

item.title: Enterprise Java spec packs bags, ready for new life under assumed name – Jakarta
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Enterprise Java, known as Java Enterprise Edition 8 (Java EE 8) under Oracle's implementation of the platform specification, has finally packed up and moved out of Big Red's basement under a new name, so it won't bear the burden of its heritage.

item.title: Jakarta EE 8 is sprinting towards an exciting future for enterprise Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: After what seemed like eternity, the time has finally come – the long awaited first release of Jakarta EE is now officially in the hands of the public.

item.title: Jakarta EE now operates under open community driven process
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: After transitioning from Oracle to the Eclipse Foundation in 2017, Jakarta EE (previously known as Java EE), has reached another major milestone.

item.title: Java EE Move to Eclipse foundation Makes Way for Cloud Native Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation has finally completed the transition of Java Enterprise Edition (EE) over to Jakarta with the release of the Jakarta EE 8 specification.

item.title: Java finally goes all in on open source with the Jakarta EE 8 release
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation has announced the release of the Jakarta EE 8, the first truly open-source, vendor-neutral version of Java Enterprise Edition.

item.title: Open Source Enterprise Java Specification Jakarta EE 8 launches
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Java Community and Eclipse Foundation introduce the designated Java EE successor, including Web Profiles, TCKs and Certified Eclipse GlassFish 5.1.

item.title: The Eclipse Foundation Releases Jakarta EE 8 Specifications
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation today announced during the JakartaOne Livestream virtual conference the release of the Jakarta EE 8 Full Platform and Web Profile specifications and related Technology Compatibility Kits (TCKs).

item.title: The Future is Now
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE 8 is finally here! It heralds a new era for Enterprise Java, as finally the community can look forward to the platform’s faster development.

item.title: The Inaugural JakartaOne Virtual Conference Goes Lives with the Release of Jakarta EE 8
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: JakartaOne Livestream is scheduled in conjunction with the formal release of Jakarta EE 8, will go live on September 10th, 2019 with the first of 19 one-hour sessions starting at 7:00am EDT.

item.title: Eclipse MicroProfile White Paper 2019
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Now Available! In the MicroProfile Technical White Paper, Lars Röwekamp explains why NOW is the best time for developers & users to adopt the MicroProfile APIs when developing microservices.

item.title: Die Zukunft von Cloud Native Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Tanja Obradovic (Jakarta EE Program Manager) and Mikael Barbero (Team Lead) explain what will change in detail with Jakarta EE and how to join the community to help shape the future of Cloud Native Java.

item.title: Why You Should Attend JakartaOne Livestream!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: If you are a server-side Java developer, you should be attending JakartaOne Livestream. As the name implies, it is a virtual conference to cover all things Jakarta EE (in case you weren't paying attention, Jakarta EE is Java EE transferred to the Eclipse Foundation from Oracle).

item.title: How to Develop Open Liberty Microservices on OpenShift
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Open Liberty is a flexible Java application server. It comes with Eclipse MicroProfile, which is a set of tools and APIs to build microservices.

item.title: J4K Conference- One Kubernetes, One Java, All Clouds
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: J4K is an exciting brand new conference that combines the best of open source and middleware communities for developing applications on Kubernetes. Check it out today!

item.title: Jakarta EE: 39 Projects and Where they are at?
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: If you are wondering what the heck is going on with Java EE and Jakarta EE, watch this awesome 40 minutes video by Triber Jean-Louis Monteiro (@JLouisMonteiro) in collaboration with Jean-Francois James recorded at JNation 2019 in Portugal.

item.title: EclipseCon Europe Call for Papers now open
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: You can now submit your proposals to be part of EclipseCon Europe 2019’s speaker lineup. The conference takes place in Ludwigsburg, Germany on October 21 - 24, 2019. Early bird submissions are due July 1, and the final deadline is July 15.

item.title: JCP Copyright Licensing request
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: We are reaching out to all companies and individuals who made contributions to Java EE in the past to help out, execute the agreements and return them back to Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Jakarta EE without javax: the world won't end this time either
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: If you missed the news, Oracle is donating the Java EE specification to the Eclipse foundation.

item.title: Eclipse Enterprise Survey Shows What Java Devs Want in 2019
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: What do enterprise Java developers want the Eclipse Foundation to prioritize as the new shepherd of Jakarta EE?

item.title: Jakarta EE and Docker: What You Should Know
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: As a Java developer, you might wonder why you should be concerned about Docker. This will show you why you should and how to use Jakarta EE.

item.title: I am an Incrementalist: Jakarta EE and package renaming
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Eclipse Jakarta EE has been placed in the position that it may not evolve the enterprise APIs under their existing package names.

item.title: Update for Jakarta EE community: May 2019
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Jakarta EE community is the driving force behind the future of cloud-native Java.

item.title: Jakarta EE has landed
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: It had been envisioned that the javax.* and jakarta.* namespaces would coexist after Java EE 8 and, as it evolved, the jakarta.* namespace would be used for new features of exiting APIs and the innovation of new APIs.

item.title: Jakarta EE has landed
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Jakarta EE platform has finished moving into its new home at the Eclipse Foundation after a year of significant effort to contribute, build, and test the Java EE technologies in a new community.

item.title: MicroProfile: What You Need to Know
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Learn everything you need to know about MicroProfile.

item.title: MicroProfile and Jakarta EE -- The Lightweight Stuff Session
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: An itkonekt session for building a MicroProfile / Java EE application from scratch. Metrics, OpenAPI, FaultTolerance, Configuration, multi-server deployments, ThinWARs, and even reactive (easter) eggs included:

item.title: MicroProfile JWT with Keycloak
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: In this tutorial, we will learn how to secure our services using MicroProfile JWT and Keycloak. Go to https://www.keycloak.org/downloads.html and download latest Standalone server distribution.

item.title: Red Hat replaces Oracle as OpenJDK 8, OpenJDK 11 steward
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Red Hat has taken control of two popular versions of the open source Java implementation, so developers can continue to build apps after Oracle's support ends.

item.title: Configuring Microservices With MicroProfile and Kubernetes
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Read on to take a look at the YAML, Java, and terminal commands you need to get your microservices up and running with MicroProfile and Kubernetes.

item.title: What’s in a Name?
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: As Wayne Beaton wrote about in his blog Renaming Java EE Specifications for Jakarta EE, the process of renaming the Java EE specifications as a part of the path towards Jakarta EE 8 has started.

item.title: Adopting Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE’s official launch is here! Have you made the switch? In this article, Edwin Derks explores three of the most common reasons why some developers haven’t moved on over and explains why Jakarta EE is worth the effort.

item.title: Easy integration testing for Java EE and MicroProfile applications with Testcontainers
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Have you ever toiled with creating mock objects for unit tests? How about custom setup steps for integration tests? Ever had an issue in production because of differences in behavior between testing and production environments?

item.title: Jakarta EE 9: 2019 Outlook
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: As Java EE moves into the Eclipse Foundation, it’s important to keep an eye on various milestones along the way. Today, Arjan Tijms of Payara explains how the transfer is going and explores some of the proposals for future EE releases.

item.title: Jakarta EE 8 Status
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Those of you following Jakarta EE probably know that the upcoming Jakarta EE 8 release will be functionally equivalent to Java EE 8. The reason for this is that we want to prove that the transfer from Oracle is complete and that we are able to produce the processes, specifications, test suites and a compatible implementation through the Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Using Jakarta EE/MicroProfile to Connect to Apache Kafka: Part 1 — Hello World
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Apache Kafka is a community-distributed streaming platform that has three key capabilities: publish and subscribe to streams of records, store streams of records in a fault-tolerant durable way, and then process streams as they occur. Apache Kafka has several success cases in the Java world. This post will cover how to benefit from this powerful tool in the Jakarta EE/MicroProfile universe.

item.title: Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 Released
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation yesterday announced the release of GlassFish 5.1, considered a major milestone release belying the modest increase in its version number.

item.title: Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 is here!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The release of Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 is an important milestone for Jakarta EE!

item.title: Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 is released
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: I am very excited to bring you some great news. Today Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 has finally been released and available

item.title: Jakarta EE Milestone - Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 is Java EE 8 Compatible
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Oracle is very pleased that Eclipse GlassFish 5.1 has been released and certified as Java EE 8 compatible.

item.title: Eclipse Glassfish 5.1.0.RC2 has been released!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: That's right, Eclipse Glassfish 5.1.0.RC2, the Jakarta EE implementation, has been published in maven central. Eclipse Glassfish 5.1.0 release is terribly close.

item.title: Jersey 2.28-RC4 has been released
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jersey 2.28-RC4 is available in maven central! Jersey 2.28-RC4, the first Jakarta EE publicly available version of Jersey, is an almost final version of Jersey 2.28.

item.title: EFSP: The Specification Committee Votes
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: One key difference between Eclipse open source software projects as defined by the Eclipse Development Process (EDP), and open source specification projects as defined by the Eclipse Foundation Specification Process (EFSP) is that specification projects must be aligned with exactly one specification committee.

item.title: Discovering JNoSQL
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: JNoSQL is an Eclipse project which, according to its definition: “is a Java framework that streamlines the integration of Java applications with NoSQL databases. It defines a set of APIs to interact with NoSQL databases and provides a standard implementation for most NoSQL databases.”

item.title: 2018 Annual Summary
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: It’s this time of the year again. Time for the yearly summary of conferences, travels, community activities, open source projects, amazing people!

item.title: Eclipse EE4J and Glassfish Now Being Fully Built and Tested as Open Source
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse EE4J project has reached a milestone of having all of it's sub-projects available in Eclipse EE4J github organization with nightly and release builds run under the Eclipse CI environment.

item.title: Jakarta EE spec process paves way for enterprise Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Eclipse will govern the future direction of enterprise Java for developers through the Eclipse Foundation Specification Process, and it pledges vendor-neutral support and IP protection.

item.title: Jakarta EE: What is it and what does it mean for Enterprise Java?
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Watch the recorded panel discussion from Oracle CodeOne's 2018 technical session.

item.title: The draft of Jakarta EE Specification Process is live!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The time has come! The Eclipse Foundation has announced the draft of the Eclipse Foundation Specification Process and invites the community to read it, review it and give feedback.

item.title: How Java EE development has kept up with microservices
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Java EE is mature technology, but it will continue to evolve in ways that can fit nicely into a microservices architecture.

item.title: JNoSQL and Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Enterprise Java platform has been evolving steadily since 1999 when it was first introduced as Java 2, Enterprise Edition. Today, Enterprise Java is being standardized under the Eclipse Foundation with the new brand, Jakarta EE. Jakarta EE picks up where Java EE 8 left off, but the roadmap going forward will be focused on modern innovations such as microservices, modularity, and, now, NoSQL databases.

item.title: Ondrej Will Be Very Busy at Oracle Code One!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Ondrej Mihalyi (Payara Engineer) will be doing not one, not two, but THREE talks at the upcoming Oracle Code One (recently changed from Java One).

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “Jakarta EE should become more modular than it is right now”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our fourth guest is Werner Keil. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Thoughts On Jakarta EE’s Vision
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is currently being formed under the Eclipse Foundation. In order to align the future development, directions, and marketing to the industry, many claim that it’s crucial for the Jakarta EE community to share a common vision or mission statement that the technology will follow.

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “The platform needs to evolve more dynamically than it had done in the past”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our third guest is Java Champion Josh Juneau. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Understanding Jakarta EE: “I strongly believe there is a lot to do to make Jakarta EE ready for the future”
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Confused about what’s going on with Jakarta EE? This interview series is meant to help you navigate through all the changes and understand where it’s headed, as well as how Jakarta EE plans to become the new home of cloud-native Java. Our second guest is Markus Eisele, Java Champion and Head of Developer Advocacy at Lightbend. Let’s dive deeper into the Jakarta EE universe!

item.title: Jakarta EE: No turning back
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is forging a new path forwards for enterprise Java. In this opinion piece, Cesar Saavedra explains why Jakarta EE is a breath of fresh air for enterprise Java.

item.title: Jakarta EE, Eclipse MicroProfile and Cloud-Native at EclipseCon France
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: These are exciting times for the Java community! EclipseCon France (ECF) 2018, the first ECF since Oracle contributed Java EE to Eclipse Foundation, surely reflected that.

item.title: Testing JavaEE backward and forward compatibility with Servlet, JAX-RS, Batch and Microprofile
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: One of the most interesting concepts that made Java EE (and Java) appealing for the enterprise is its great backward compatibility, ensuring that years of investment in R&D could be reused in future developments.

item.title: 2018 Java Ecosystem Executive Insights
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Take a look at what more than a dozen executives have to say about the Java ecosystem and what's on the horizon.

item.title: Proposed Jakarta EE Design Principles
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Let's take a look at some suggested design principles that some feel Jakarta EE should follow. What suggestions do you have?

item.title: Lightbend Podcast: Why Lightbend Joined The Eclipse Foundation’s Jakarta EE Working Group (9 Min)
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: In this Lightbend Podcast, we sit down with our CEO, Mark Brewer, to discuss what joining the Eclipse Foundation as a founding member of the Jakarta EE Working Group means for bringing Reactive closer to the traditional Java enterprise landscape.

item.title: Enter Jakarta EE: an Inoculation Against Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt in the Java Community
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Why I stopped worrying and learned to love changes in governance and branding.

item.title: Enterprise Java in the Blogosphere
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: So much has happened in the enterprise Java space over the past few months that it kind of boggles the mind.

item.title: ​Where does Java in the enterprise go from here?
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Oracle recently freed J2EE, aka Java EE. Now known as Jakarta EE, enterprise Java's new manager the Eclipse Foundation is revealing its plans for the popular middleware platform.

item.title: Proprietary to Open: A Sea Change for Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Although a big part of this is the brand change from Java EE to Jakarta EE as well as a new technical direction (i.e. cloud-native and microservices) the most important change will be the move from a proprietary Java EE to fully open source Jakarta EE platform.

item.title: Latest Roundup of EE4J Activities for Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: There has been a recent flurry of EE4J activity as the Eclipse Foundation is positioning Jakarta EE as the new home for cloud native Java.

item.title: Java roadmap: Eclipse’s Jakarta EE enterprise Java takes shape
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The Eclipse Foundation outlines the 39 projects that will make up the new cloud-native, microservices-friendly enterprise Java effort, and how GlassFish will evolve.

item.title: Goodbye, Java Enterprise Edition. Hello, Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Developers who use Java Enterprise Edition will be happy to know that the development and runtime platform is gaining new life as Jakarta EE. As part of an agreement with Oracle, the tech giant will give up control over the platform to Eclipse Foundation, which has big plans to remake enterprise Java for the emerging cloud world.

item.title: Background on Oracle’s contribution to Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: We are on our way to making the contribution we proposed last September a reality!

item.title: The road to Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE launch is a good occasion to reflect on how we got here…

item.title: The Eclipse Foundation has established Jakarta EE Working Group
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Fujitsu is now a Strategic Member of Eclipse Foundation and will be an active member of the Eclipse Board of Directors and Jakarta EE.

item.title: In Support of Jakarta EE’s Quest to Accelerate Cloud Native Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: The right environment is now in place to reinvigorate Java’s most popular run-time platform with an open source-first approach and a commitment to truly putting the community into Jakarta EE.

item.title: Jakarta EE - the new home for enterprise Java
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Official Moving Day! New Open Community Stewardship and Governance Model now with Eclipse Foundation.

item.title: Jakarta EE is Officially Out!
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: Jakarta EE is officially out! With Jakarta EE all of us involved in working towards the release hope that we can use it as a catalyst to bring together communities under a single banner.

item.title: The Future of Cloud Native Open Source Java with Jakarta EE
item.author: webdev@eclipse-foundation.org (Christopher Guindon)
item.description: It's here! The Eclipse Foundation has announced the future of Java EE with the release of Jakarta EE: a cloud-native Java and an open source governance model.
